channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel will be back on air on Tuesday, Disney says
item.description: The late night comic was suspended last week under pressure from the Trump administration after comments about Charlie Kirk's killing.
item.content:encoded:
The late night comic was suspended last week under pressure from the Trump administration after comments about Charlie Kirk's killing.

(Image credit: Ronald Martinez)
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: Unease grows at the Justice Department as Trump's threats get even more blunt
item.description: President Trump is directing the Justice Department to prosecute his perceived political enemies, upending the career ranks and raising questions about selective prosecution.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump is directing the Justice Department to prosecute his perceived political enemies, upending the career ranks and raising questions about selective prosecution.

(Image credit: Tasos Katopodis)
item.dc:creator: Carrie Johnson

item.title: July 4 wildfire in Grand Canyon still burning, questions about response still unanswered
item.description: The Dragon Bravo fire continues to burn in remote pockets of the park. Federal officials have not yet provided details on their response to lawmakers.
item.content:encoded:
The Dragon Bravo fire continues to burn in remote pockets of the park. Federal officials have not yet provided details on their response to lawmakers.

(Image credit: A. Sage-Morris)
item.dc:creator: Ryan Heinsius

item.title: Supreme Court allows Trump to fire -- for now -- remaining Democrat on FTC
item.description: At issue is whether the president has the authority to dismiss the heads of those agencies that are protected by Congress.
item.content:encoded:
At issue is whether the president has the authority to dismiss the heads of those agencies that are protected by Congress.

(Image credit: Win McNamee)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: When will fall foliage peak near you? Here are some leaf-peeping predictions
item.description: Leaves typically start to peak in northern states by early October, but projecting peak foliage isn't an exact science. Here are some things you can do to get the most out of fall's colors.
item.content:encoded: Leaves typically start to peak in northern states by early October, but projecting peak foliage isn't an exact science. Here are some things you can do to get the most out of fall's colors.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: 400 entertainers co-sign ACLU letter supporting Jimmy Kimmel
item.description: Celebrities including Pedro Pascal and Selena Gomez wrote: "Our government has resorted to threatening the livelihoods of journalists, talk show hosts, artists, creatives and entertainers."
item.content:encoded: Celebrities including Pedro Pascal and Selena Gomez wrote: "Our government has resorted to threatening the livelihoods of journalists, talk show hosts, artists, creatives and entertainers."
item.dc:creator: Anastasia Tsioulcas

item.title: Man charged with attempted assassination of Trump rests own case
item.description: Ryan Routh, who is accused in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump on his golf course last year, called three witnesses and rested his defense after only a few hours of testimony on Monday.
item.content:encoded:
Ryan Routh, who is accused in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump on his golf course last year, called three witnesses and rested his defense after only a few hours of testimony on Monday.

(Image credit: Lothar Speer)
item.dc:creator: Greg Allen

item.title: USDA cancels survey tracking how many Americans struggle to get enough food
item.description: The Department of Agriculture said it will end a longstanding annual food insecurity survey. Experts say the move will obscure the effects of recent changes that will lead to people losing food aid.
item.content:encoded:
The Department of Agriculture said it will end a longstanding annual food insecurity survey. Experts say the move will obscure the effects of recent changes that will lead to people losing food aid.

(Image credit: Brandon Bell)
item.dc:creator: Jordan-Marie Smith

item.title: Trump blames Tylenol for autism. Science doesn't back him up
item.description: President Trump and his deputies tied autism to acetaminophen use during pregnancy, presented a cancer drug as a possible treatment, and said the FDA would change labeling to reflect both claims. There is little strong scientific evidence for either.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump and his deputies tied autism to acetaminophen use during pregnancy, presented a cancer drug as a possible treatment, and said the FDA would change labeling to reflect both claims. There is little strong scientific evidence for either.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: Jon Hamilton

item.title: Deal for TikTok creates U.S. joint venture, and government won't have a stake
item.description: The U.S. will get a copy of TikTok's prized content recommendation algorithm, and that the tech company Oracle will provide security.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. will get a copy of TikTok's prized content recommendation algorithm, and that the tech company Oracle will provide security.

(Image credit: ROBYN BECK)
item.dc:creator: John Ruwitch
